title: GLA MONTHLY GRIDS from NOAA-11 V001
name: gla-monthly-grids-from-noaa-11-v001
notes: This dataset contains the TIROS Operational Vertical Sounder (TOVS)n                  level 3 geophysical parameters derived using the physical retrievaln                  method of Susskind et al. (1984) and processed by the Satellite Datan                  Utilization Office of the Goddard Laboratory for Atmospheres atn                  NASA/GSFC. This method, which is hydrodynamic model- and a priorin                  data-dependent, is designated as the so-called Path A scheme by then                  TOVS Pathfinder Science Working Group. The 20 channel High resolutionn                  Infrared Radiation Sounder 2 (HIRS2) and the 4 channel Microwaven                  Sounding Unit (MSU) aboard the NOAA-xx series of Polar Orbitingn                  Satellites are used to produce global fields of the 3-dimensionaln                  temperature-moisture structure of the atmosphere. In addition ton                  profiles of temperature and moisture, the HIRS2/MSU data are used ton                  derive important quantities such as land and sea surface temperature,n                  outgoing longwave radiation, cloud fraction, cloudtop height, totaln                  ozone overburden and precipitation estimates.n                  n                  The Path A system steps through an interactiven                  forecast-retrieval-analysis cycle. In each 6 hour synoptic period, an                  2nd order General Circulation Model (Takacs et al., 1994) is used ton                  generate the 6 hour forecast fields of temperature and humidity. Thesen                  global fields are used as the first guess for all soundings occuringn                  within a 6 hour time window centered upon the forecast time. Thesen                  retrievals are then assimilated with all available insitu measurementsn                  (such as radiosonde and ship reports) in the 6 hour interval using ann                  Optimal Interpolation (OI) analysis scheme developed by the Datan                  Assimilation Office of the Goddard Laboratory for Atmospheres. Thisn                  analysis is then used to specify the initial conditions for the next 6n                  hour forecast, thus completing the cycle.n                  n                  The retrieval algorithm itself is a physical method based on then                  iterative relaxation technique originally proposed by Chahinen                  (1968). The basic approach consists of modifying the temperaturen                  profile from the previous iteration by an amount proportional to then                  difference between the observed brightness temperatures and then                  brightness temperatures computed from the trial parameters using then                  full radiative transfer equation applied at the observed satelliten                  zenith angle. For the case of the temperature profile, the updatedn                  layer mean temperatures are given as a linear combination ofn                  multichannel brightness temperature differences with the coefficientsn                  given by the channel weighting functions. Constraints are imposed uponn                  the solution in order to ensure stability and convergence of then                  iterative process. For more details see Susskind et al (1984).n                  n                  There are 6 level 3 data product files, each of which is in the HDFn                  format and each representative of a different averaging timen                  period. All files contain the same number of geophysical parametern                  arrays stored as HDF Scientific Data Sets (SDSs). The time periodsn                  include daily, 5 day (pentad) and monthly, with the AM and PM portionsn                  of the orbits treated separately.  All data are mapped to a 1 degreen                  longitude by 1 degree latitude global grid.

organization.description: NASA's vision: To reach for new heights and reveal the unknown so that what we do and learn will benefit all humankind.rnrnTo do that, thousands of people have been working around the world -- and off of it -- for 50 years, trying to answer some basic questions. What's out there in space? How do we get there? What will we find? What can we learn there, or learn just by trying to get there, that will make life better here on Earth?rnrnNASA conducts its work in four principal organizations, called mission directorates:rn rnAeronautics: works to solve the challenges that still exist in our nation's air transportation system: air traffic congestion, safety and environmental impacts.rnrnHuman Exploration and Operations: focuses on International Space Station operations, development of commercial spaceflight opportunities and human exploration beyond low Earth orbit.rnrnScience: explores the Earth, solar system and universe beyond; charts the best route of discovery; and reaps the benefits of Earth and space exploration for society.rnrnSpace Technology: rapidly develops, demonstrates, and infuses revolutionary, high-payoff technologies, expanding the boundaries of the aerospace enterprise.rnrnIn the early 21st century, NASA's reach spans the universe. The Mars rover Curiosity is still exploring Mars to see if it might once have had environments suitable for life. Cassini is in orbit around Saturn, as Juno makes its way to Jupiter. The restored Hubble Space Telescope continues to explore the deepest reaches of the cosmos as NASA developes the James Webb Space Telescope.rnrnCloser to home, the latest crew of the International Space Station is extending the permanent human presence in space. With commercial partners such as SpaceX, NASA is helping to foster the development of private-sector aerospace.rnrnEarth science satellites are sending back unprecedented data on Earth's oceans, climate and other features. NASA's aeronautics team is working with other government organizations, universities, and industry to fundamentally improve the air transportation experience and retain our nation's leadership in global aviation.
organization.title: National Aeronautics and Space Administration
